column1: Cockeysville is a census-designated place (CDP) in Baltimore County

Cockeysville was named after the Cockey family who helped establish the town. Thomas Cockey (1676–1737) settled in Limestone Valley in 1725 at Taylor's Hall (an area now just north of Padonia Road and east of Interstate 83). Joshua Frederick Cockey (1765–1821) built one of the first homes in the area in 1798 and built the first commercial structure
column3: in 1810 in what would become the village of Cockeysville. His son
column5: was a lifelong resident in the village. As a businessman before being appointed as judge
column6: in the 1830s he built the train station (which would be a stop on the Pennsylvania Railroad) and accompanying commercial buildings.

column1: Cockeysville was the scene of some Civil War activity. Confederate soldiers pushed into the Baltimore area
column2: intending to cut off the city and Washington from the north. On July 10
column4: Confederate cavalry under General Bradley T. Johnson entered Cockeysville
column5: destroying telegraph lines and track along the Northern Central Railway. They also burned the first bridge over the Gunpowder Falls

column2: Joshua F. Cockey III (1837–1920) founded the National Bank of Cockeysville (1891) and other commercial ventures in the community
column3: as well as developing dwellings along the York Turnpike (now York Road) that made up the village of Cockeysville.

column1: Stone Hall was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1973. Baltimore County School No. 7 was listed in 2000.
Cockeysville is home to the Cockeysville Branch of the Baltimore County Public Library and the Historical Society of Baltimore County.

column5: and on the west by rural Baltimore County. Most commercial activity is concentrated along York Road.According to the United States Census Bureau

column1: The Maryland Transit Administration's Light RailLink line runs through Cockeysville. The Warren Road stop is the stop in the area.
Bus Route 93 operates along York and some other roads in the area.
The area used to be served by the Northern Central Railway
column2: a wholly owned subsidiary of the Pennsylvania Railroad (PRR). Located on the PRR's Baltimore-Harrisburg mainline
column3: Cockeysville saw the passage of many named interstate passenger trains as late as the 1960s
column4: such as the Liberty Limited and the General to Chicago.

column1: President Abraham Lincoln traveled through Cockeysville on the Northern Central Railway en route to Gettysburg
column3: to deliver the Gettysburg Address in 1863.  Less than two years later
column6: Lincoln's funeral train also passed through Cockeysville on its way from Washington
column8: to his final resting place at Springfield
column10: the Baltimore Light RailLink uses the corridor established by the predecessors of the Northern Central; the corridor north is now the Torrey C. Brown Rail Trail.
